John Edward : Language skills that are indispensable to global citizens

Independent schools in Scotland have a track record of top academic quality , which continued with outstanding results in 2018 , as well as individual and group successes in sport , art , music and other community activities .
With over 30,000 students across Scotland , these schools , represented by the Scottish Council of Independent Schools ( SCIS ) , seek to offer their students and parents the best level of service .
Independent schools are designed to prepare students – for further education , including at universities , for their desired careers , and for their role as world citizens .
In the education sector , we have the opportunity to develop and implement a tailor-made schooling curriculum , whereby modern languages are still popular and desired in schools .
Nelson Mandela once said , “ If you talk to a person in the language he understands , you will reach his mind . ”
When you speak with him in his own language , it goes to his heart . ”
This makes it impressive that we cannot rely solely on the English language if we want to build relations and trust with people from other countries .
The results of this year show that languages are at the forefront of tables with the highest quotas in independent schools .
68 percent of students who have studied foreign languages have reached the so-called “ Higher grade A ” higher class A .

The data collected by the 74 SCIS member schools showed that 72 percent of students reached a “ Higher grade A ” in Mandarin , while 72 , 69 and 63 attended Note A among the students who learned German , French and Spanish .
This shows that independent schools in Scotland promote foreign languages as essential skills that children and young people will undoubtedly need in the future .
Language subjects have the same rank in the curricula of independent schools and elsewhere as MINT subjects ( mathematics , information technology , science and technology ) .
A 2014 British Commission survey on Employment and Qualifications revealed that 17 % of the reasons employers had difficulty filling vacancies are attributable to a lack of linguistic knowledge .
As a result , language skills are becoming increasingly necessary to prepare young people for their professional future .
Given the more promising employment opportunities that languages require , these skills are essential in a globalised world .
Regardless of the career that someone chooses when learning a second language , he will have a real advantage in the future with a lifelong ability like this .
Through the possibility of communicating directly with people from abroad , a multilingual person will automatically be ahead of the competitors .

According to a YouGov survey of more than 4,000 adults in the UK in 2013 , 75 % were unable to speak a foreign language well enough to talk , and French is the only language spoken with a double-digit percentage , namely 15 % .
That is why the current investment in language teaching is important for today 's children .
When children learn to speak several languages – especially those of developing countries – they will later have better opportunities to find meaningful employment in the labour market .
The schools in Scotland differ in their language offerings .
Some schools focus on classical modern languages , while other languages that are most important for Britain in 2020 , such as Mandarin or Japanese , will teach .
Whatever your child 's interests , there will always be a number of languages available in independent schools , with teachers specialised in this field .

Independent schools in Scotland want to provide a learning environment that is well prepared for children , and they should be given the necessary tools for their success , whatever the future may bring .
In today ’ s global business world , languages are undeniably still important for the country ’ s future , and this must also be reflected in education .
Indeed , modern languages should really be regarded as “ international communication skills . ”
Independent schools will continue to offer young people in Scotland this choice , diversity and top quality .
Il faut bien le faire .
